chapter.title: Templates
chapter.para: The templates collection provides information about the virtual machine templates in a Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization environment. An API user accesses this information through the rel="templates" link obtained from the entry point URI (see ).
The following table shows specific elements contained in a virtual machine template resource representation.

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

A link to the network interface sub-collection for virtual machine resources
A link to the cdroms sub-collection for virtual machine resources
A link to the sub-collection for virtual machine permissions. See
The type of virtual machine the template provides. A list of enumerated values are available in capabilities. See
One of ILLEGAL, LOCKED or OK
The amount of memory allocated to the guest, in bytes
The CPU topology (i.e. number of sockets and cores) available to the guest
A list of boot devices, described by a dev attribute on a boot element. A list of enumerated values are available in capabilities. See
A path to a kernel image which the template is configured to boot from
A path to an initrd image to be used with the kernel above
A kernel command line parameter string to be used with the kernel above
A reference to the template's host cluster. See
A reference to the VM on which this template is based. See
A reference to the template's domain.
The date and time at which this template was created
One of rhev, vmware or xen
The system from which this template originated
Set enabled to true if the VM should be automatically restarted if the host crashes. A priority element controls the order in which VMs are re-started
The display type (either vnc or spice), port, and the number of monitors
A stateless template contains a snapshot of its disk image taken at boot and deleted at shutdown. This means state changes do not persist after a reboot
Defines the USB policy for a virtual machine template. Requires an enabled element set to a boolean value.

chapter.para: Creation of a new template requires the name and vm elements. Identify the vm with the id attribute or name element. See for more information.

example.title: Creating a template from a virtual machine
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/templates HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-type: application/xml
<template> <name>template1</name> <vm id="082c794b-771f-452f-83c9-b2b5a19c0399"/> </template>

chapter.para: The name, description, type, memory, cpu topology, os, high_availaility, display, stateless, usb and timezone properties are updatable post-creation. See for more information.

example.title: Updating a virtual machine template to contain 1 GB of memory
example.screen:
PUT /restapi-definition/templates/284t367e-332y-935u-26u9-u9n3l56e8429 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-type: application/xml
<template> <memory>1073741824</memory> </template>

chapter.para: Removal of a virtual machine template requires a DELETE request.

section.title: Export Action
section.para: The templates collection contains an export action. Information on the action for importing templates is found in .

The export action exports a template to an Export storage domain. A destination storage domain is specified with a storage_domain reference. By default, the export action overwrites any existing template with the same name in the destination domain. The exclusive parameter set to true avoids this.
